We define the jump of an element b of a labeled poset (P,) 
by considering the number of strict edges on each of the saturated chains from b down to a minimal element of P, and taking the maximum such number.
The jump sequence of (P,), denoted (P,), is 

    (P,) = (j_0, ‚Ä¶ j_k),

where j_i is the number of elements with jump i, and k is the maximum jump of an element of (P,).

sentence: Any balanced JDM realization can be represented as a set of almost semi-regular bipartite graphs and almost regular graphs. The realization then can be constructed from these factor graphs as their labeled union: the vertices with the same labels are collapsed, and the edge set of the union is the union of the edge sets of the factor graphs.

Let G be a graph and œÉ be an ordering of its vertices. An ‚Ñì-bucketing of œÉ is a function 
	T V(G) ‚Üí [‚Ñì] such that T(u)‚â§ T(v) for any u appearing before v in œÉ. 
	For every i‚àà [‚Ñì], the set T^-1(i) will be called a bucket; a bucket is naturally ordered by œÉ. 
	
	For every bucket T^-1(i), i ‚àà [‚Ñì], let (G,œÉ,T,i) be the family of œÉ-cuts containing on one side all vertices of buckets appearing before 
	i and a prefix (in œÉ) of the i-th bucket.
	For an ordering œÉ of the vertices of a graph G, define the width of the bucket i, i‚àà[‚Ñì], as the maximum width of any cut in the family (G,œÉ,T,i).
	Formally,
	
    (G,œÉ,T,i)     =    {(T^-1([1,i-1]) ‚à™ L,   R ‚à™ T^-1([i+1,‚Ñì])) . 
          ¬†¬†. (L,R)œÉT^-1(i)},
    (G,œÉ,T,i)     =    max{ |E_G(L,R)|  (L,R) ‚àà(G,œÉ,T,i) }.

Let (G,xÃÖ) be a k-boundaried graph and let S = {x_1,‚Ä¶,x_k,x_1',‚Ä¶,x_k'}‚äÜ V(G^*). 
	
	
	Let now œÉ be an ordering of V(G^*) and T be an ‚Ñì-bucketing of œÉ.

    T^-1_j(i)  =

    {v‚àà T^-1(i) v_j<_œÉ v<_œÉ v_j+1}    j‚àà [p-1],
    {v‚àà T^-1(i) v_p<_œÉ v }    j=p.

	Let also (G,œÉ,T,i,j) be the family of œÉ-cuts containing on one side all vertices 
	appearing before v_j-1 (or, if j=0, all vertices of buckets appearing before 
	bucket i) and a prefix (in œÉ) of T^-1_j(i). For an ordering œÉ of the vertices of a graph G, 
	define the width of j-th segment T^-1_j(i) of the bucket i, i‚àà[‚Ñì], j‚àà [0,p],

	Formally,
	
    (G,œÉ,T,i,j)     =    {(T^-1({1,‚Ä¶,i-1})‚à™ L, T^-1({i+1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì})‚à™ R) . 
          ¬†¬†. (L,R)œÉT^-1(i)v_j‚àà Lv_j+1‚àà R},
    (G,œÉ,T,i,j)     =    max{ |E_G(L,R)|  (L,R) ‚àà(G,œÉ,T,i,j) }.

sentence:
For k,‚Ñì‚àà‚Ñï, a (k,‚Ñì)-bucket profile consists of functions:
	
		
  * b,b': [k] ‚Üí [‚Ñì] identifying the buckets which contain x_i and x_i', respectively,
		
  * p,p':[k]‚Üí [k] highlighting the ordering between the vertices x_i and x_i' inside a bucket, respectively,
		
		
  * ŒΩ: [‚Ñì]√ó [0,k] ‚Üí [0,k] corresponding to the widths of segments of buckets defined by the vertices x_i, respectively.
	
	


	
	A k-boundaried graph ùêÜ conforms with a (k,‚Ñì)-bucket profile,
	if there exists an ordering œÉ of the vertices of G^* and an ‚Ñì-bucketing T such that:
		
		
	
		
  * T(v) is odd for v‚àà V(G) and even for v‚àà{x_1',‚Ä¶,x_k'},
		
  * T(x_i) = b(i) and T(x_i') = b'(i), for each i‚àà [k],
		
  * p(i)<p(j), if b(i)=b(j) and x_i<_œÉ x_j, and p'(i)<p'(j) if b'(i)=b'(j) and x_i'<_œÉ x_j',
		
		
		
  * (G, œÉ|_G, T|_G, j,s) = ŒΩ(j,s), for each j‚àà [‚Ñì] and s‚àà [0,k].

sentence:
[Manipulation point]
  For a ranking x ‚àà L_q, write a x> b to denote
  that the alternative a is preferred by x over b. A social
  choice function f  L_q^n ‚Üí [q] is
  manipulable at x ‚àà L_q^n if there exist a y ‚àà L_q^n
  and i‚àà [n] such that x and y only differ in the i'th
  coordinate and
  
    f(y) x_i> f(x)

  In this case we also say that x is a manipulation point of f,
  and that (x,y) is a manipulation pair for f.
  We say that f is manipulable, if it is manipulable at some point x.
  We also say that x is an r-manipulation point of f,
  if f has a manipulation pair (x,y) such that y is obtained from
  x by permuting (at most) r adjacent alternatives in one of the
  coordinates of x.

sentence:
Fix q‚â• 4 and
  distinct a,b,c,d ‚àà [q].
  Then the canonical path between x ‚àà L_q and z ‚àà L_q
  is x, y, z where y is obtained from z by swapping a and b if
  necessary in order to assure that a and b are in the same order as in x.
  This first step is called a Type I move while the second step from y
  to z is called a Type II move .

sentence:
Let X be a nonempty set and let r: X√ó X ‚ü∂
X√ó X be a bijective map. We use notation (X,r) and refer
to it as a quadratic set . The image of (x,y) under r is
presented as

    r(x,y)=(^xy,x^y).

The formula (<ref>) defines a ‚Äúleft action" : X√ó X
‚ü∂ X, and a ‚Äúright action" : X√ó X
‚ü∂ X, on X as:

    _x(y)=^xy,   _y(x)= x^y,

for all x, y ‚àà X. The map  r is nondegenerate , if the
maps _x and _x are bijective for each x‚àà X.   In
this paper we shall always be interested in the case where r is nondegenerate,  as
will be indicated. As a notational tool, we  shall often identify
the sets X√ó X and X^2, the set of all monomials of length
two in the free semigroup ‚ü® X‚ü©.

sentence:
* r is square-free if r(x,x)=(x,x) for all x‚àà X.

  *  r is a set-theoretic solution of the
Yang-Baxter equation or, shortly a solution
 (YBE) if  the braid relation

    r^12r^23r^12 = r^23r^12r^23

holds in X√ó X√ó X, where the two bijective maps
r^ii+1: X^3 ‚ü∂ X^3, 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ 2 are
defined as  r^12 = r√ó Id_X, and r^23=Id_X√ó r. In
this case some authors also call (X,r)   a braided set .
If in addition r is involutive (X,r) is called a
symmetric set .

sentence:
Let (X,r) be a quadratic set.

(i) The semigroup

    S =S(X, r) = ‚ü® X; (r) ‚ü©,

 with a
set of generators X and a set of defining relations (r),
is called the semigroup associated with (X, r) .

(ii) The group G=G(X, r) associated with (X, r) is
defined as

    G=G(X, r)=_gr‚ü® X;  (r) ‚ü©.


(iii) For arbitrary fixed field k, the k-algebra
associated with (X ,r) is defined as

    = (k,X,r) = k‚ü® X ‚ü©/((r)).



If (X,r) is a solution, then S(X,r), resp. G(X,r), resp.(k,X,r) is called the Yang-Baxter semigroup, resp.the Yang-Baxter group, resp. the Yang-Baxter
algebra associated to (X,r).

sentence:
Let (X,r_X) and (Y, r_Y) be arbitrary solutions
(braided sets).
A map œÜ: X ‚ü∂ Y is a homomorphism of
solutions, if it satisfies the equality

    (œÜ√óœÜ) ‚àò r_X =
    r_Y‚àò (œÜ√óœÜ).

A bijective homomorphism of solutions  is called (as usual)
an isomorphism of solution.
An isomorphism of the solution
(X,r) onto itself is an r-automorphism .


We denote by Hom((X,r_X),(Y,r_Y)) the set of all homomorphisms
of solutions œÜ: X ‚ü∂ Y. The group of
r-automorphisms of (X, r) will be denoted by (X, r).
Clearly, Aut(X,r) is a subgroup of Sym(X).

is r-invariant if r(X√ó X) ‚äÜ X√ó X. In

sentence:
Define the shifted code of a strict partition Œª to
be the infinite sequence of letters R and U obtained from the
shifted Young diagram of shape Œª as follows.  Consider the
shifted Young diagram top and left aligned in the 4^th
quadrant of the xy-plane together with the positive x-axis.
Starting at the bottom right corner of the leftmost box in the last
row, trace along the rightmost edge of the shifted Young diagram,
then right along the positive x-axis.  Equivalently, start the
code at the lowest place where the line y=-x intersects the
shifted Young diagram.  The shifted code of the strict partition is
the sequence of R's and U's obtained from this path, where R
corresponds to a unit right step and U corresponds to a unit up
step.

  For two k-sort sets U and V, a k-sort function œÉ is a k-sort bijection if each component is a set bijection.
  For k-sort sets of cardinality c_1, c_2, ‚Ä¶, c_k, denote by c_1, c_2, ‚Ä¶, c_k = c_1√óc_2√ó‚Ä¶√óc_k the k-sort symmetric group , the elements of which are in natural bijection with k-sort bijections from a k-sort set to itself.
  Finally, denote by FinBij^k the category of finite k-sort sets with k-sort bijections.

sentence:
Define an orientation of a hedron to be a cyclic ordering of the set of its fronts and an orientation of a k-tree to be a choice of orientation for each of its hedra.
  If two oriented hedra share a front, their orientations are compatible if they correspond under the mirror bijection.
  Then an orientation of a k-tree is coherent if every pair of adjacent hedra is compatibly-oriented.

Let X be a Coxeter graph and let w ‚àà W_c(X).  Then w is left weak star reducible by s with respect to t to sw if 


  * w is left star reducible by s with respect to t; 

and

Observe that (1) implies that m(s,t) ‚â• 3 and that s ‚àà≈Å(w).  Furthermore, (2) implies that l(tw)>l(w).  We analogously define right weak star reducible .  If w is left weak star reducible by s with respect to t, then we define

and refer to ‚ãÜ_s,t^L as a left weak star reduction .  Similarly, if w is right weak star reducible by s with respect to t, we define
	
    ‚ãÜ^R_s,t(w)=ws

and refer to ‚ãÜ_s,t^R as a right weak star reduction .  If there is a (possibly trivial) sequence

sentence:
Let k be a nonnegative integer.  The standard k-box is a rectangle with 2k marks points, called nodes (or vertices ) labeled as follows.





    < g r a p h i c s >




We will refer to the top of the rectangle as the north face and the bottom as the south face .  Often, it will be useful for us to think of the standard k-box as being embedded in the plane.  In this case, we put the lower left corner of the rectangle at the origin such that each node i (respectively, i') is located at the point (i,1) (respectively, (i,0)).

sentence: A concrete pseudo k-diagram consists of a finite number of disjoint curves (planar), called edges , embedded in the standard k-box.  Edges may be closed (isotopic to circles), but not if their endpoints coincide with the nodes of the box.  The nodes of the box are the endpoints of curves, which meet the box transversely.  Otherwise, the curves are disjoint from the box.  We define an equivalence relation on the set of concrete pseudo k-diagrams.  Two concrete pseudo k-diagrams are (isotopically) equivalent if one concrete diagram can be obtained from the other by isotopically deforming the edges such that any intermediate diagram is also a concrete pseudo k-diagram.  A pseudo k-diagram (or an ordinary Temperley-Lieb pseudo-diagram ) is defined to be an equivalence class of equivalent concrete pseudo k-diagrams.  We denote the set of pseudo k-diagrams by T_k(‚àÖ).

sentence:
Let d ‚àà T_n+2().  That is, the blocks on the edges of d consist of sequences of the decorations , , , and .


  * An edge of d is called L-exposed (respectively, R-exposed ) if it can be deformed to touch the left (respectively, right) wall of the diagram without crossing any other edges.

  * We call d L-decorated (respectively, R-decorated ) if the only edges labelled with closed (respectively, open) decorations are L-exposed (respectively, R-exposed).

  * We call d LR-decorated if d is both L-decorated and R-decorated, with the added constraint that it must be possible to deform decorated edges so as to take open decorations to the left and closed decorations to the right simultaneously.  We denote the set of LR-decorated diagrams from T_n+2() by T_n+2^LR().


  * We say that a decoration on a non-propagating edge e joining i to j (respectively, i' to j') with i<j (respectively, i'<j') is first (respectively, last ) if it is the first (respectively, last) decoration encountered as we traverse e from i to j (respectively, i' to j').


  * Similarly, if (d)=1, then we say that a decoration on a propagating edge e from i to j' is first (respectively, last ) if it is the first (respectively, last) decoration encountered as we traverse e from i to j'.

of all walks from u to v in G. Then we call the complete -metric graph A=(G,d') the shortest path completion of G.

Given an -metric graph we also denote by ùí≤(u,v) a shortest path connecting u to v such that its -length is d'(u,v) (there can be multiple of them, in that case pick an arbitrary one).

sentence:
An L-structure A is irreducible if 
A is not a free amalgamation of two proper substructures of A.

sentence:
An -graph is an L_-structure where all relations are symmetric and irreflexive and every pair of vertices is in at most one relation. (Alternatively, a graph with edges labelled by M^‚âª 0).

An -metric graph us an -graph which is a non-induced substructure of an -metric
space (interpreted as L_-structure) such that all relations are symmetric.

Every -graph that is not -metric is a non--metric graph .

sentence:
[Morse relations, <cit.>]
		Let ùîΩ be a field, M a combinatorial manifold of dimension d and f an rsl function on M. Then the following holds, where Œ≤_i(M; ùîΩ):=_ùîΩ H_i(M; ùîΩ) denotes the i-th Betti number:
		
		
			
  * Œº_i(f; ùîΩ)‚â•Œ≤_i(M; ùîΩ) for all i,
			
  * ‚àë_i=0^d (-1)^iŒº_i(f; ùîΩ)=œá(M)=‚àë_i=0^d (-1)^iŒ≤_i(M; ùîΩ),
			
  * M is (k-)tight with respect to ùîΩ if and only if Œº_i(f; ùîΩ)=Œ≤_i(M; ùîΩ) for every rsl function f and for all 0‚â§ i ‚â§ d (for all 0‚â§ i‚â§ k).
		

		Functions satisfying equality in (i) for all i ‚â§ k are called k-tight functions . A function f that satisfies equality in (i) for all i is usually referred  to as perfect or tight function, cf. <cit.>.

sentence:
[stacked polytope, stacked sphere <cit.>] 
									
  * A simplex is a stacked polytope and each polytope obtained from a stacked polytope by adding a pyramid over one of its facets is again stacked.
			
			
  * A triangulation of the d-sphere S^d is called stacked d-sphere if it is combinatorially isomorphic to the boundary complex of a stacked (d+1)-polytope.

sentence:
[rsl functions, <cit.>]
		Let M be a combinatorial manifold of dimension d. A function f: M is called regular simplex-wise linear ( rsl , for short), if f(v)‚â† f(v') for any two vertices v‚â† v' of M and f is linear when restricted to any simplex of M. Regular simplex-wise linear functions are sometimes also referred to as Morse functions .

		Let ùîΩ be a field, M be a combinatorial d-manifold and let f be an rsl function on M. A vertex v‚àà M is called critical of index k and multiplicity m with respect to f , if
				
    _ùîΩ H_k(M_v,M_v\v;ùîΩ)=m>0,

				where M_v:=x‚àà M:f(x)‚â§ f(v) and H_* denotes an appropriate homology theory with coefficients in ùîΩ. The number of critical points of f of index i (with multiplicity) are
		
		
    Œº_i(f; ùîΩ):=‚àë_v‚àà V(M)_ùîΩ H_i(M_v,M_v\v;ùîΩ).

sentence: [k-stacked balls and spheres, <cit.>]A k-stacked (d+1)-ball , 0‚â§ k‚â§ d, is a triangulated (d+1)-ball that has no interior j-faces, 0‚â§ j‚â§ d-k. An admissible vertex labelling of a pure d-dimensional simplicial
    complex X is a map

    ‚Ñì:V(X)‚ü∂{0}

    such that no two adjacent vertices obtain opposite labels, that is, such that
    ‚Ñì(v)‚â†-‚Ñì(w) for {v,w}‚àà E(X).

    Under such a labelling, a +alternating facet is one that
    obtains labels +j_0,-j_1,+j_2,‚Ä¶,(-1)^dj_d with
    0<j_0<j_2<‚Ä¶<j_d (that is, all labels have different absolute
    values, and if we order them by absolute value, then the signs alternate, starting
    with a positive sign).  Similarly, a -alternating facet 
    obtains labels -j_0,+j_1,-j_2,‚Ä¶,(-1)^d+1 j_d with
    0<j_0<j_2<‚Ä¶<j_d.

sentence:
Let (N,W) be a simple game.


  (i) Player i is at least as desirable as j
(i ‚âø  j, in short) in (N,W) if

    S‚à™{j}‚àà W ‚áí S‚à™{i}‚àà W,    for all   S‚äÜ N ‚àñ{i,j}.


  (ii) Players i and j are equally desirable
(i ‚âà j, in short) in (N,W) if

    S‚à™{i}‚àà W ‚áî S‚à™{j}‚àà W,    for all    S ‚äÜ N‚àñ{i,j}.


  (iii) Player i is strictly more desirable
than player j (i ‚âª j, in short) in (N,W) if i is at least
as desirable as j, but i and j are not equally desirable.

sentence:
A simple game (N,W) is complete or linear if the
desirability relation is a complete preordering.

sentence:
Let (N,W) be a simple game.


  i) i ‚àà N is a dictator in (N,W) if W^m = {{ i }},

  ii) i ‚àà N has veto in (N,W) if i ‚àà S for all S ‚àà W,

  iii) i ‚àà N is a passer in (N,W) if { i }‚àà W, 

  iv) i ‚àà N is null in (N,W) if i ‚àâ S for all S ‚àà W^m.

  v) i ‚àà N has semi-veto in (N,W) if i ‚àà S for all S ‚àà W 
      with the only exception of coalition N ‚àñ{i} which is also a winning coalition.

  vi) i ‚àà N is a semi-passer in (N,W) if { i,j }‚àà W
      for all j ‚àà N ‚àñ{i}, but { i }‚àâ W.

sentence:

sentence:
The extension of a graph G formed by replacing each vertex v ‚àà V(G) by some type of gadget h(v) will be termed unbiased if the resulting graph G' has the following properties:
 
  
  * Whenever |d(u)| = |d(v)| for some u,v ‚àà V(G), the graphs induced on h(u) and h(v) are isomorphic.
  
  
  * ‚àÄ  u,v ‚àà V(G),  ‚àÉ Œ≥‚àà Aut(G')   such that  Œ≥ : h(u) ‚Ü¶ h(v) if and only if ‚àÉ œÜ‚àà Aut(G)    such that  œÜ : u ‚Ü¶ v,
  
  * For any x,y ‚àà V(G') such that x ‚àà h(u) and y ‚àà h(v) where u ‚â† v, we have {x,y}‚àà E(G') only if {u,v}‚àà E(G).

sentence:

Then a subgraph S ‚äÇ G is connected cell-wise symmetrically (or CWS) within G, alternatively termed a cell-wise symmetric (or CWS) subgraph of G, relative to œÄ(G), if:
 
    ‚àÄ  u,v ‚àà V(S)  such that Œ∏(u) = Œ∏(v),   we have   d(u)|_(G\ S) = d(v)|_(G\ S).

 In other words, any elements of S in the same cell of œÄ(G) have identical neighbour sets outside S (in G\ S).

sentence: Consider the graph G' in which all pairs of non-isomorphic mutually m-equivalent subgraphs of G are replaced by isomorphic mutually m-equivalent graphs of the same m-equivalence class, for all m ‚â• k. In the case where the subgraphs A_x are not k-equivalent, S is unchanged. It follows that G' ‚àº_k G, however all mutually m-equivalent subgraphs of G' now belong to a single isomorphism class. Then elements of S are said to be mutually CWS (or alternatively said to be connected CWS to each other) within G, if for all A_x, A_y ‚àà S, there exists a œï‚ààAut(G') such that œï(A_x) = A_y (and hence S is in this sense vertex-transitive).

sentence:
The family M_k of graphs is defined as including those graphs for which the k-dim WL method has been shown to fail to partition the vertex set down to its orbits. and not including graphs for which the (k+1)-dim WL method has been shown to fail in this sense. All graphs G ‚àà M_k have the following properties:
 
  
  * G and G are connected.
  
  * G contains two non-isomorphic, mutually CWS subgraphs S_1,S_2, each connected CWS to G relative to the colour classes of WL_k(S_i) |_S_i.
  
  * G contains no pair of non-isomorphic, mutually CWS, m-equivalent subgraphs, where m > k.

sentence:
[Canonical Contraction]

 For each colour class c_i ‚ààWL_k(G) with members in S, denote
 
    [c_i]_S = { v ‚àà [c_i] : v ‚àà S }.

 Since S is a CWS subgraph of G, a vertex w ‚àà V(G \ S) can be said to be connected to a colour class of S, in that if {v,w}‚àà E(G) for some v ‚àà [c_i]_S, then {v',w}‚àà E(G) for all v' ‚àà [c_i]_S. 

 For each w ‚àà V(G \ S), denote by w_S = {(c_r,Œ≥_1), ‚Ä¶, (c_t, Œ≥_t)} the set of colour classes c_i such that w is connected to [c_i]_S by edges of colour Œ≥_i.
 The canonical contraction of G relative to a subgraph S ‚äÇ G, resulting in a graph G^'_S, proceeds as follows.
 
  
  (i) Replace S by a single vertex x coloured by the isomorphism class of S.
  
  (ii) Replace the edges connecting [c_i]_S to w ‚àà V(G \ S) by a single edge {x,w} coloured by c_i, for all such w.
  
  (iii) Where w ‚àà V(G \ S) is connected to multiple colour classes in S, replace the resulting multiple edges by a single edge coloured by each such colour class, such that:
  
  (iv) Edges {w,x} and {w^',x} have the same colour if and only if Sort(w^_S) = Sort(w'_S).

sentence:
[Bohr intervals and cyclic progressions]
Let ùïã:=‚Ñù/‚Ñ§ with the usual topology.  The elements of ùïã are cosets a+‚Ñ§, where a‚àà‚Ñù, so every subset of ùïã may be identified with a set E+‚Ñ§, where E‚äÜ [0,1]‚äÜ‚Ñù.  An interval in ùïã is a set of the form [a,b]+‚Ñ§, where a, b‚àà‚Ñù and  0<b-a‚â§ 1.    We will abuse notation and write [a,b] for the set [a,b]+‚Ñ§ contained in ùïã.

Let Œª denote Haar probability measure on ùïã. Note that if I and J are intervals in ùïã then I+J is an interval, and Œª(I+J)=min{1,Œª(I)+Œª(J)}.


  Let G be an abelian group and Œº a translation invariant probability measure on G.  We say that A‚äÜ G is a Bohr interval if there is a surjective Œº-measurable homomorphism œÑ:G‚Üíùïã and an interval I‚äÜùïã such that A=œÑ^-1(I).

  If A, B‚äÜ G are Bohr intervals, we say that A and B are parallel if there is a single surjective Œº-measurable homomorphism œÑ:G‚Üíùïã and intervals I, J‚äÜùïã such that A=œÑ^-1(I) and B=œÑ^-1(J).



If N‚àà‚Ñï, we say that A‚äÜ G is an N-cyclic progression[This terminology is not standard, but it satisfies our desire to include the cardinality of the group ‚Ñ§/N‚Ñ§ in the terminology, as a bound on N is stated in Theorem <ref>.] if there is a surjective Œº-measurable homomorphism œÑ:G‚Üí‚Ñ§/N‚Ñ§ and an arithmetic progression P‚äÜ‚Ñ§/N‚Ñ§ of common difference 1 such that A=œÑ^-1(P).

  If A and B are N-cyclic progressions, we say that A and B are parallel if there is a single surjectice Œº-measurable homomorphism œÑ:G‚Üí‚Ñ§/N‚Ñ§ such that A=œÑ^-1(P) and B=œÑ^-1(Q) for arithmetic progressions P, Q‚äÜ‚Ñ§/N‚Ñ§ of common difference 1.


   If K‚â§ G is a  Œº-measurable finite index subgroup of G, C'‚äÜ K is a Bohr interval in K, and a‚àà G, we say that a+C' is a relative Bohr interval in G.  A relative N-cyclic progression
 is defined similarly.

sentence:
[Periodicity] Given a subgroup K‚â§ G, a set A‚äÜ G is a union of cosets of K if and only if A=A+K.  The latter equation will often be used as an abbreviation of the assertion ‚ÄúA is a union of cosets of K.‚Äù   We may call such a set A periodic with respect to K.

 If A‚àº_Œº A+K, we say that A is essentially periodic with respect to K.  When A is essentially periodic with respect to K, then A is Œº-similar to a union of cosets of K, but the converse does not hold. For example, if G is an infinite compact abelian group with Haar probability measure Œº, K‚â§ G is a proper open subgroup, c‚àâ K, and A=K‚à™{c}, then A‚àº_Œº K but A_Œº A+K.

sentence:
[Quasi-periodicity]
  Let K‚â§ G be a Œº-measurable subgroup with Œº(K)>0.  We say that A‚äÜ G is quasi-periodic with respect to K if A can be partitioned into two sets A_1 and A_0, where A_0‚â†‚àÖ, (A_1+K)‚à© A_0=‚àÖ, A_1‚àº_Œº A_1+K, and A_0 is contained in a coset of K.  For such A_1, A_0,  the expression A_1‚à™ A_0 is called a quasi-periodic decomposition of A with respect to K , or simply a quasi-periodic decomposition , if the group K is clear from context.

  If Œµ>0, we say that A‚äÜ G is Œµ-quasi periodic with respect to K if A=A_1‚à™ A_0, where A_0‚â†‚àÖ, (A_1+K)‚à© A_0=‚àÖ, A_1 is Œµ-periodic with respect to K, and A_0 is contained in a coset of K.

sentence:
Call f: G‚Üí‚ÑÇ a strong character of ùêÜ if there are characters œá_n‚ààG_n such that f=lim_n‚Üíùí∞œá_n. Equivalently, f is a strong character of G if f=^‚àò(‚àè_n‚Üíùí∞œá_n), where œá_n‚ààG_n for ùí∞-many n.  Every strong character is Œº-measurable by Part (ii) of Proposition <ref>.  One can easily verify that every strong character is a homomorphism from G to ùíÆ^1. Write G for the set of strong characters of G, and note that G is a group under pointwise multiplication.[We do not refer to a topology on G when we define G, in contrast to the dual G of a locally compact abelian group G, which (by definition) grants G the topology of uniform convergence on compact subsets of G.]



A weak character of G is a Œº-measurable homomorphism œÅ: G‚ÜíùíÆ^1.  Of course every strong character is also weak character, and Lemma <ref> says that every weak character of G is a strong character of G, motivating our choice of the notation G.

We say that two ŒΩ-measurable subsets A, B of G form a critical pair if ŒΩ_*(A+B)<ŒΩ(A)+ŒΩ(B).  We say they form a tame critical pair if, in addition, A+B is ŒΩ-measurable, the stabilizer H:=H(A+B) is ŒΩ-measurable, and

    ŒΩ(A+B)=ŒΩ(A+H)+ŒΩ(B+H)-ŒΩ(H).
 In other words, A, B is a tame critical pair if it satisfies the conclusion of Theorem <ref>.

sentence:
[Tameness and type]
We say that A, B is a tame subcritical pair if ŒΩ_*(A+B)=ŒΩ(A)+ŒΩ(B) and there is a ŒΩ-measurable finite index subgroup K‚â§ G such that A,B, and K satisfy one of the conclusions (I)-(III) of Proposition <ref>.  If A, B, and K satisfy conclusion (I), we say that the triple A, B,  K has type (I) , and similarly for the other conclusions. We say that A, B has type (I) if there exists a finite index subgroup K‚â§  G such that A, B,  K has type (I), and similarly for the other types.

When the ambient group is compact, the terms ‚Äútame‚Äù and ‚Äútype‚Äù can be applied, simply replacing Proposition <ref> with Theorem <ref> in the definition.

The corresponding reflection for the hyperplane H_Œ±,m will be denoted by s_Œ±,m and by H_Œ±,m^+ and H_Œ±,m^- we denote the two corresponding (closed) half-spaces.

A connected component of ‚àñ H^ùîû is called open alcove and its closure (closed) alcove .

sentence:
Let Œ± be a simple root. An alcove Œî_i of Œ¥ is called Œ±-stable if there exists m ‚àà and 0 ‚â§ l ‚â§ i < r ‚â§ p+1, such that


  * Œî_r' ‚äÇ H_Œ±,m,

  * Œî_l' ‚äÇ H_Œ±,m, and

  * for all l ‚â§ s < r : Œî_s' ‚äÑH_Œ±,m-1.


If the index m is minimal such that the indices l and r exist we say that Œî_i is Œ±-stable at m , in this case we denote by r_Œ±(Œî_i) the minimal index such that properties (i) and (iii) are fulfilled and by l_Œ±(Œî_i) the maximal index such that properties (ii) and (iii) are fulfilled.

Let R_Œ±,m(Œ¥) be the set of all indices j, such that Œî_j is Œ±-stable at m and

sentence: An ordered set {x_1, x_2, ‚Ä¶, x_k} of vertices of G^2 is called a bridging set if for each i, 1‚â§ i‚â§ k, x_i ‚àà N(s) ‚àñ D' and there exists a vertex q_i ‚àà Q such that Œº(q_i)=Œº(x_i) and q_i is not adjacent in G^2 to at least one vertex in D'‚à™{x_1,x_2, ‚Ä¶, x_i-1}. Denote q_i = bp(x_i) and call it the bridging partner of x_i. We also fix one vertex in D'‚à™{x_1, x_2, ‚Ä¶, x_i-1} not adjacent to q_i in G^2, denote it by bn(q_i), and call it the bridging non-neighbor of q_i. (If there are more than one candidates, we fix one of them arbitrarily as the bridging non-neighbor.)

 such that A_11,B_21‚àà‚Ñ≥_r√ó n, with 1‚â§ r‚â§ m-1, and neither A_11=B_21, nor A_21=B_11.

 such that A_11,B_12‚àà‚Ñ≥_m√ó s, with 1‚â§ s‚â§ n-1, and neither A_11=B_12, nor A_12=B_11.

sentence:
A weighted bicolored plane tree, or a weighted tree, or just a
tree for short, is a bicolored plane tree whose edges are endowed 
with positive integral weights. The sum of the weights of the edges 
of a tree is called the total weight of the tree. 

The degree of a vertex is the sum of the weights of the edges incident to this 
vertex. Obviously, the sum of the degrees of black vertices, as well as the sum of the
degrees of white vertices, is equal to the total weight n of the tree. Let the tree
have p black vertices, of degrees _1,‚Ä¶,_p, and q¬†white vertices,
of degrees _1,‚Ä¶,_q, respectively. Then the pair of partitions (,),
,‚ä¢ n, is called passport of the tree.

The weight distribution of a weighted tree is a partition 
Œº‚ä¢ n, Œº=(Œº_1,Œº_2,‚Ä¶,Œº_m) where m=p+q-1 is 
the number of edges, and Œº_i, i=1,‚Ä¶,m are the weights 
of the edges. Leaving aside the weights and considering only the
underlying plane tree, we speak of a topological tree, which is a bicolored
plane tree. Weighted trees whose weight distribution is Œº=1^n will 
be called ordinary trees: they coincide with the corresponding topological trees.

distinguished edge itself is called its root. We consider the
root edge as being oriented from black to white.

sentence:
Let X,Y ‚äÜ G_k be fixed.
Suppose that H ‚àà(n,k) is such that every entry of H is contained in X,
and that M ‚àà(m,‚Ñì) is such that every eigenvalue of ‚àö(m)^-1M is contained in Y.

Then the pair (H, M) is (X,Y)-sound if


  * For each Œ∂_k^j‚àà X, we have ‚àö(m)^1-j M^j‚àà(m, ‚Ñì).

  * For each Œ∂_k^j‚àà Y, we have H^(j)‚àà(n,k).

We will often say that (H,M) is a sound pair if there exist sets X and Y for which (H, M) is (X, Y)-sound.

sentence:
A set-valued shifted tableau T of shifted shape Œª is a filling of the boxes with finite, nonempty subsets of primed and unprimed positive integers so that 

 
  * the smallest number in each box is greater than or equal to the largest number in the box directly to the left of it (if that box is present),
  
  * the smallest number in each box is greater than or equal to the largest number in the box directly to the above it (if that box is present),
 
  * any positive integer appears at most once, either primed or unprimed, but not both, and
 
  * there are no primed entries on the main diagonal.

sentence:
A K-Young-Fibonacci (KYF) tableau is a filling of a snakeshape with positive integers such that


 
  (i) for any pair  B 
 A  the inequality A‚â§ B holds;
 
  (ii) to the right of any  B 
 A , there are no numbers from the interval [A,B] 
 in either the upper or lower rows;
 
  (iii) if the position above  A  is not occupied yet, then to the right of 
  A  there are no numbers greater than or equal to A in either the lower or upper rows;

  (iv) any pair  A 
 A  must come before any single box  B  
and must not be in rightmost column of the snakeshape. In addition, A may not be the smallest entry in the snakeshape.

sentence:
A list assignment on a graph G is a function  that
  assigns to each vertex v a set of colors (v). A (proper)
  partial edge coloring is -saturating if for every vertex
  v and every color c ‚àà(v), some edge incident to v receives
  the color c. A graph G is -saturable if it has an
  -saturating partial edge coloring.  When f is a function from

sentence:
Let P be a set with distinguished elements called 0, 1. Suppose ¬∑ is a binary operation and + a partial binary operation on P. A partial field is a quintuple

    := (P,+, ¬∑,0,1)

satisfying the following axioms:


    
  * (P‚àñ{0},¬∑,1) is an abelian group.
    
  * For all p ‚àà P, p + 0 = p.
    
  * For all p ‚àà P, there is a unique element q ‚àà P such that p + q = 0. We denote this element by -p.
    
  * For all p, q ‚àà P, if p+q is defined, then q+p is defined and p+q=q+p.
    
  * For all p,q,r ‚àà P, p¬∑(q+r) is defined if and only if p¬∑ q+p¬∑ r is defined. Then p¬∑ (q+r) = p¬∑ q+p¬∑ r.

  * The associative law holds for +.

[Elementary graph <cit.>]

colors (one color on each edge) in such a way that every induced
two-edge path has its two edges colored differently.

sentence:
[Peculiar graph <cit.>]
A graph G is peculiar if V(G) can be partitioned into nine
sets A_i, B_i, Q_i (i=1,2,3) that satisfy the following
properties for each i, where subsbcripts are understood modulo¬†3:


  * Each of the nine sets is non-empty and induces a clique.

  * A_i is complete to B_i‚à™ A_i+1‚à™ A_i+2‚à™ B_i+2 and
not complete to B_i+1.

  * B_i is complete to A_i‚à™ B_i+1‚à™ B_i+2‚à™ A_i+1 and
not complete to A_i+2.

  * Q_i is complete to A_i+1‚à™ B_i+1‚à™ A_i+2‚à™ B_i+2 and
anticomplete to A_i‚à™ B_i‚à™ Q_i+1‚à™ Q_i+2.

We say that (A_1, B_1, A_2, B_2, A_3, B_3, Q_1, Q_2, Q_3) is a
peculiar partition of G.

sentence:
[Flat edge augmentation]
Let xy be a flat edge in a graph G, and let A be a cobipartite
graph such that V(A) is disjoint from V(G) and V(A) can be
partitioned into two cliques X,Y.  We obtain a new graph G' by
removing x and y from G and adding all edges between X and
N_G(x) ‚àñ{y} and all edges between Y and N_G(y)
‚àñ{x}.  This operation is called augmenting the flat
edge xy with the cobipartite graph A.  In G' the pair (X,Y) is
called the augment .

sentence:
A tropical polynomial is a function F: ^d-1‚Üí that can be expressed
as the tropical sum of a finite number of tropical monomials . 
More precisely, if we let  denote (X_1,‚Ä¶,X_d-1), then a tropical
polynomial F is the maximum
	
    F = max_I‚àà‚Ñ¨ F_I(X_1,‚Ä¶, X_d-1) = 
    	    max_I‚àà‚Ñ¨ F_I()
 of a
        finite set {F_I| I ‚àà‚Ñ¨}
        of linear functionals[In tropical geometry one typically
  uses integer or rational coefficients, because these coefficients come
        from valuations of power series, but in this paper everything
will make sense for real coefficients.]
	F_I: ^d-1‚Üí.
The tropical hypersurface V(F) is the set of points in
	^d-1 where F is non-differentiable.  Equivalently, V(F) is
the set of points where the maximum among the terms of F is achieved
at least twice.

Let S^d-1 denote the unit sphere in ^d.
A half-space is said to be homogeneous if the defining hyperplane

is called an outer normal vector .

for which the inner product n ¬∑ x is negative.

A d-1-dimensional spherical simplex is
the intersection of S^d-1 and d homogeneous half-spaces in ^d.
Up to congruence, a spherical simplex is determined by the d2
pairwise angles enclosed by the outer normal vectors of the d half-spaces.
If these d2 angles are all equal, then we say that
the spherical simplex is regular .

Fix c > 0, let H be a 4-graph on n vertices, and let {A, B} be a bipartition of V(H).

sentence:
[structure, pattern, chosen label]
 A structure X is a graph whose vertices are labelled with either pairwise distinct elements of  (we call such vertices fixed ) or pairwise distinct intervals in  (we call such vertices free ), and whose edges are labelled with either pairwise distinct elements of  ( fixed ) or with distinct choices of special symbols _1 or _2 ( free ). When dealing with structures, we identify vertices and edges with their labels. So, vertices in X are numbers or intervals and edges in X are numbers or special free symbols _1 and _2.
 
 In any structure, we require that if u and v are fixed vertices and uv is a fixed edge, we have uv=|u-v|, and such that each free edge has one endpoint fixed and the other free. We write
 (_i;X)
 (_i;X):=|a-min(I)| for such a free edge _i with fixed endpoint labelled a and free endpoint labelled I. We write (X)(X) for the set of free vertex labels in X, and (X) (X)for the set of free edge labels in X.  We write (X)(X) for the total number of free (vertex- or edge-) labels in X. 
 
Suppose that we are given structures X and X'. We say that X' follows the pattern X if (X')=0 and there is a graph isomorphism œÅ from X' to X such that for each vertex u‚àà X' the labels satisfy either u=œÅ(u) or u‚ààœÅ(u), and for each edge uv‚àà X' the labels satisfy either uv=œÅ(uv) or uv‚ààœÅ(uv). We call the labels of vertices u‚àà X' such that u‚ààœÅ(u), and of edges uv‚àà X' such that uv‚ààœÅ(uv), chosen labels . We write X'XX'X for the set of chosen vertex labels in X' and X'XX'X for the set of chosen edge labels in X'.
 
 Given A‚äÇ and C‚äÇ, and a structure X, we write 
 
    X(A,C)
 for the set of all structures following the pattern X whose chosen vertex labels are in A and whose chosen edge labels are in C.

sentence:
Let G be a directed or undirected graph with node-set V.


  * A node v ‚àà V is said to be a 
cut-vertex if its removal increases the number of (undirected)
graph components of G. Denote the set of cut-vertices by V^cut.


  * Consider the connected (undirected) components of G after
removing all cut-vertices and the edges containing them. To each
component, add back the cut-vertices to which it was connected in G,
together with the connecting edges. These induced subgraphs of G are
called the strong blocks .


  * If G is undirected (directed), we say G is (strongly)
connected if for all v ‚â† w ‚àà V there exists a (directed) path
from v to w. Note that strong blocks are (strongly) connected.

sentence:
Call a pair of adjacent vertices whose removal disconnects
		a given graph G, a bottleneck pair .
		Consider removing all the bottleneck pairs from¬†G. We are left with connected components of G. 
		Now, consider any bottleneck pair (x,y). Suppose that x and y were earlier adjacent to a set of vertices S_x and S_y of a connected component C_i.
		Then create a copy of (x,y) and re-connect them with edges with the vertices of S_x and S_y respectively. Do this with every bottleneck pair of G.
		Call the subgraphs of G so formed as reduced subgraphs of G.

    x_n=œÑ(Œ¥(q_0,_U(n))),  ‚àÄ n‚â• 0.

C_M‚ààùîê_c(G) and C_m‚ààùî™_c(G). The subgraph obtained by deleting the vertex

and |C_p|‚â•|C_m|+1, with the graph G, is called as the edge inserted graph. We denote such graph as ‚Ñê_C_m[G].

sentence:
An n-vertex graph G is said to be a stationary graph if the vertex set is partitioned into t+1 subsets
V_0,‚Ä¶,V_t, where n‚â• t+1‚â•4, and the edge distribution follows the following four properties.


  * V_0 and V_t are non-empty and if for some integer i, with 1‚â§ i‚â§ t-1, V_i is empty then both V_i-1 and V_i+1 are non-empty.

  * [G]V_i,V_i=0 for each integer i, with 0‚â§ i‚â§ t.

  * [G]V_i,V_i+1=0 for each integer i, with 0‚â§ i‚â§ t-1.

  * If 0<|V_i|‚â§ |V_j|, where i and j are integers with 0‚â§ i,j‚â§ t and |i-j|‚â•2, then for each x‚àà V_i 
there exists a unique y‚àà V_j such that {x,y} is an edge. 
(So [G]V_i,V_j=|V_i|=min{|V_i|,|V_j|}.) 

Also such partition or its dual partition (The dual partition of V_0,‚Ä¶,V_t is VÃÖ_0,‚Ä¶,VÃÖ_t, where VÃÖ_i:=V_t-i for each integer i with 0‚â§ i‚â§ t.) satisfies exactly one of following properties.


  * ||V_i|-|V_j||‚â§1 for all integers i and j, with 0‚â§ i,j‚â§ t.

  * |V_0|=|V_1|+1=|V_2|+2=|V_3|, whenever t=3.

  * |V_0|+1=|V_1|=|V_2|+2=|V_3|, whenever t=3.

  * |V_0|=|V_1|+2=|V_2|=|V_3|, whenever t=3.

  * |V_0|=|V_1|+3=|V_2|=|V_3|, whenever t=3.

  * |V_0|=|V_1|+2=|V_2|=|V_3|+1=|V_4|, whenever t=4.

  * |V_0|=|V_1|+2=|V_2|=|V_3|+2=|V_4|, whenever t=4.

  * |V_0|=|V_1|=|V_2|+2=|V_3|=|V_4|, whenever t=4.

sentence:
<cit.> Let G be a simple graph with n vertices.  The complement GÃÖ of G is defined 
to be the simple graph with the same vertex set as G and where two vertices u 
and v are adjacent precisely when they are not adjacent in G.  Roughly speaking 
then, the complement of G can be obtained from the complete graph K_n by 
rubbing out all the edges of G.

sentence:
<cit.> Two vertices that are not adjacent in a graph G
are said to be independent . A set S of vertices is independent if any two vertices of S are independent. The vertex independence number or simply the independence number , of a graph G, denoted by  Œ±(G) is the maximum cardinality among
the independent sets of vertices of G.

sentence: <cit.> A subset M of the  edge set of G, is called a matching in G if no two of the edges in M are adjacent. In other words, if for any two edges e and f in M, both the end vertices of e are different from the end vertices of f.

sentence: <cit.> A perfect matching of a graph G is a matching of G containing n/2 edges, the largest possible, meaning perfect matchings are only possible on graphs with an even number of vertices.  A perfect matching sometimes called a complete matching or 1-factor.

sentence: <cit.> The matching number of a graph G, denoted by ŒΩ(G), is the size of a maximal independent edge set. It is also known as edge independence number . The matching number ŒΩ(G)  satisfies the inequality ŒΩ(G)‚â§‚åän/2‚åã. Equality occurs only for a perfect matching and graph G has a perfect matching if and only if |G|=2¬†ŒΩ(G), where |G|=n is the vertex count of G.

A complete sun is a sun G where the induced subgraph  ‚ü® U‚ü© is complete.

The Left stop and Right stop of a combinatorial game G, denoted by LS(G) and RS(G) respectively, are recursively defined as

    LS(G)   =
        	x    if  G=x  is a number,
    max_G^L‚àà G^‚Ñí{RS(G^L)}   otherwise;
        
    
    RS(G)   =
        	x    if  G=x  is a number,
    min_G^R‚àà G^‚Ñõ{LS(G^R)}   otherwise.

sentence: Two combinatorial games G and H are called infinitesimally close if LS(G-H)=0 and RS(G-H)=0. A game infinitesimally close to 0 is called an infinitesimal .

sentence:

if G is not an integer and there is no s<t such that GÃÉ_s is infinitesimally close to a number x;

sentence: Given a game G, the ordered pair (LS(G_t), RS(G_t)), regarded as a pair of functions of t, is called the thermograph of G.

sentence:
Given a class of games S, the boiling point of S, denoted BP(S), is the supremum of the temperatures of all games in S, thus

    BP(S)=sup_G‚àà S(t(G)).

sentence: Let G be a hot game. Then (G^L,G^R) is called a pair of thermic options of G if t(G)=t({G^L| G^R}). We set G={G^L|G^R} where G^L=G^L and G^R=G^R are thermic options. We say G is a thermic version of G.

sentence:
Let G be a hot game and G a thermic version of G. Let  t_0=0,t_1,t_2,‚Ä¶,t_k=t(G) be the sequence of the vertical coordinates of the turning points of the left boundary of the thermograph of G. The Right stops of the sequence of G^L(i)=G^L_t_i-t_i define the segments of the boundary. If RS(G^L(i+1))=RS(G^L(i)), we have a vertical segment; on the other hand, if RS(G^L(i+1))<RS(G^L(i)), we have an oblique segment. Define

  
  * t_i to be left vertical if RS(G^L(i+1))=RS(G^L(i));
  
  * t_i to be left oblique if RS(G^L(i+1))<RS(G^L(i)).

We further define 
    T^L_=‚àë_t_i is left
    vertical (t_i+1-t_i)
 and 
    T^L_=‚àë_t_i is left
    oblique (t_i+1-t_i).

Right vertical, right oblique, T_^R, and T_^R are defined similarly.

sentence:
[Radin and Yin¬†<cit.>]
Consider the function

    ‚Ñì(x) := Œ≤_1 x + Œ≤_2 x^p - x log x - (1-x) log (1-x),     0‚â§ x‚â§ 1.

For each (Œ≤_1,Œ≤_2) 
the function ‚Ñì has either one or two local maximizers.
There is a curve Œ≤_2 = q(Œ≤_1), Œ≤_1 ‚â§Œ≤_1^c, with the endpoint

    (Œ≤_1^c,Œ≤_2^c)=(log(p-1) - p/p-1,p^p-1/(p-1)^p),

such that off the curve and at the endpoint, ‚Ñì has a 
unique global maximizer, while on the curve away from the 
endpoint, ‚Ñì has two global 
maximizers 0 < x_1 < x_2 < 1. 
The curve q is continuous, decreasing and is called the phase transition curve .

sentence: A Dyck path of size n is a lattice path going from (0,0) to (n,n), using only north and east steps and staying weakly above the line x=y (also called the main diagonal ). The set of Dyck paths of size n will be denoted by ùñ£(n). A partially labelled Dyck path is a Dyck path whose vertical steps are labelled with (not necessarily distinct) non-negative integers such that the labels appearing in each column are strictly increasing from bottom to top, and 0 does not appear in the first column. The set of partially labelled Dyck paths with m zero labels and n nonzero labels is denoted by (m,n).

Fix n,m,a,b‚àà‚Ñï, n‚â• 1, m,a,b‚â• 0. For every Dyck path D‚ààùñ£(n+m) with |(D)|‚â• a, |(D)|‚â• b and |(D)|‚â• m choose three subsets of {1,‚Ä¶, m+n}:

A partial ovoid is a set of points in a polar space such that each generator contains at most one
point of this set. It is called an ovoid if each generator contains precisely one point of the set.

sentence:
Let n and k be non-negative integers with k‚â§n/3. We
  define the following four graphs (see also
  Figure¬†<ref>).[The constructions for
    E_2(n,k) and E_4(n,k) do not give unique graphs. We collectively
    denote all graphs constructed in this way by E_2(n,k) and E_4(n,k),
    respectively. In the following we only use properties of these graphs that
    are shared by all of them.]
  
  
  * Let X Y_1 Y_2 with |X|=k,
    |Y_1|=‚åàn-k/2‚åâ, and
    |Y_2|=‚åän-k/2‚åã be the vertices of E_1(n,k). Insert
    all edges intersecting
    
    
    X, and between¬†Y_1 and¬†Y_2.
  
  * The second class of extremal graphs is defined only for k<n-1/4.
    Let X Y_1 Y_2 with |X|=2k+1,
    |Y_1|=‚åän/2‚åã, and |Y_2|=‚åàn/2‚åâ-2k-1 (or
    |Y_1|=‚åàn/2‚åâ, and
    |Y_2|=‚åän/2‚åã-2k-1) be the vertices of E_2(n,k).
    Insert all edges within X, and between Y_1 and X‚à™ Y_2.  
    If¬†n is odd, this construction captures two graphs, if¬†n is even
    just one.

  
  * Let X Y_1 with |X|=2k+1 and |Y_1|=n-2k-1  be the vertices of
    E_3(n,k). Insert all edges intersecting X.

   
  * The fourth class of extremal graphs is defined only for k‚â•n/6-2. When k‚â•n-2/3 take E_4(n,k) to be the complete graph K_n. Otherwise, the vertex set is formed by five disjoint sets X, Y_1, Y_2,
    Y_3, and Y_4, with |Y_1|=|Y_3|, |Y_2|=|Y_4|,
    |Y_1|+|Y_2|=n-3k-2, and |X|=6k-n+4. Insert  all edges in
    X, between X and Y_1‚à™ Y_2, and between Y_1‚à™ Y_4 and
    Y_2‚à™ Y_3. Thus the choice of |Y_1| determines a
    particular graph in the class E_4(n,k). All
    graphs in E_4(n,k) have the same number of edges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let¬†G' be a graph and let ' be a triangle factor in¬†G'.  An
  improving rotation on a set V' is a set of vertex
  disjoint triangles¬† in¬†V' which witnesses either that ' is not of maximum size, or that its choice does not maximise the
  matching number of G'-V('): We can replace those triangles of¬†' which are contained in¬†V' by the triangles¬†
  and obtain a triangle factor¬†‚Äù with one of the following two
  properties. Either |‚Äù|>|'|, or |‚Äù|=|'| but the matching
  number of G'-V(‚Äù) is bigger than that of G'-V(').  If, on the
  other hand, |‚Äù|=|'| and the matching number of G'-V(‚Äù) equals
  that of G'-V(') then¬†V' is a non-improving rotation or
  simply rotation.  In both cases we also say that we can rotate
  from¬†' to¬†‚Äù.

sentence:
[connect, favour]connectfavour
  Given two triangles¬†T and¬†T', we say that a third
  triangle¬†T‚Äù connects T to T', or that there is a connection from T to T' via T‚Äù, if one of the following two
  conditions holds.
  
    
  * There are at least 8 edges from T‚Äù to both T and T', or
    
  * There are 9 edges from T‚Äù to T, and at least 7 from
      T‚Äù to T'.
  
  To emphasise that the definition is not symmetric in T and T' we say that
  the connection favours T and also write T T‚Äù T'.

The k-total dominating graph D_k^t(G) of G is the graph whose
vertices correspond to the total dominating sets of G that have cardinality
at most k. Two vertices of D_k^t(G) are adjacent if and only if the
corresponding total dominating sets of G differ by either adding or deleting
a single vertex. For r‚â•0, we abbreviate D_Œì_t(G)+r^t(G) to
D_Œì_t+r^t(G), and D_Œ≥_t(G)+r^t(G) to D_Œ≥
_t+r^t(G).

sentence:
[Keyed and palindromic generalised h-vectors]

Suppose a generalised h-vector has the form

    h(Œî) = ‚àë h_k(Œî)w_k

where each h_k is a homogeneous polynomial, each k is a key

Œî =  h_k +  k.  If all this holds, we say that h
is a keyed generalised h-vector.  If each h_k is
palindromic we say that h is palindromic .

sentence:
Given a tree position (C,œï) and a pair of edges e, g of C,
define the adjacency weight

    a(e,g) = w(R(e) ‚à© R(g)) = w(eg,ge)

to be the sum of the weights of the edges of G that pass through both
e and g or equivalently the sum of the weights of edges of G between
boundary vertices in eg  and boundary vertices in ge. 


Define the slope 

    s(e,g)    = w(R(g) ‚àñ R(e)) -  w(R(e) ‚à© R(g))
       = w(ge‚àñeg, ge) - w(eg,ge)

to be the sum of the weights of the edges of
G that pass through g but not through e  minus 
the sum of the weights of edges of G that
pass through both edges.
The slope s(e,g) is the amount that the width of edge e changes 
if edge g is disconnected from the tree and reattached on the far side
of e.

and whose second endpoint is not a boundary vertex.

each directed edge e in Œì, such that Œ≥_e(-x) = -Œ≥_e(x)
and such that each Œ≥_e is zero-preserving (Œ≥_e(0) = 0), monotone (Œ≥_e(x) ‚â•Œ≥_e(y) if x ‚â• y), and continuous.

sentence:
A voltage function on a graph with boundary Œì is a function œï from the vertices of Œì to ‚Ñù.  A current function
on Œì is a function Œπ from the directed edges of Œì to ‚Ñù, such that

    Œπ(e) = -Œπ(e)

and such that for every vertex v in the interior of Œì, ‚àë_eŒπ(e) = 0, where the sum ranges over all edges leaving the vertex v.  A
voltage function œï and current function Œπ are compatible (with respect to some conductance network on Œì) if

    Œπ(e) = Œ≥_e(œï(x) - œï(y))

whenever e is an edge leading from vertex x to vertex y.  Given such a pair, the boundary voltage function is the restriction
of œï to ‚àÇŒì, while the boundary current function is the function that assigns to each vertex v ‚àà‚àÇŒì,
the sum ‚àë_e Œπ(e) where e ranges over the edges leaving from v.

sentence:

sentence:
A bijective network is a graph Œì with boundary, and a function that assigns to each directed edge e in Œì,
a conductance function Œ≥_e:‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù, which satisfies the following properties:


  * Œ≥_e(0) = 0

  * Œ≥_e is a bijection for every e

  * Œ≥_e(-x) = -Œ≥_e(x)

We say that the network if monotone if every Œ≥_e is order-preserving (x ‚â• y ‚áíŒ≥_e(x) ‚â•Œ≥_e(y)), and we say that the
network is linear if every Œ≥_e is linear (of the form Œ≥_e(x) = c_ex for some c_e ‚àà‚Ñù).

For a fixed graph Œì with boundary, a bijective conductance structure on Œì is a choice of the functions Œ≥_e.

sentence:
If Œì is a bijective network with n boundary nodes, then the Dirichlet-Neumann relation is the relation Œõ‚äÜ‚Ñù^n √ó‚Ñù^n consisting of all pairs (u,f), where u is the boundary voltage of a voltage function œï, f is the boundary current of a current function
Œπ, and œï and Œπ are compatible.

sentence:
A graph Œì with boundary is strongly recoverable if no two distinct bijective network structures on Œì have the same Dirichlet-Neumann relation.
Œì is weakly recoverable if no two distinct monotone linear bijective network structures on Œì have the same Dirichlet-Neumann relation.

sentence:
Let Œì be a graph with boundary.  We say that Œì is circular planar if it can be embedded in a disk D
with all boundary vertices on ‚àÇ D and all interior vertices in the interior of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If Œì is a circular planar graph with boundary (with a fixed planar embedding), then a covoltage function on Œì
is an arbitrary real-valued function on the faces of Œì.  If œà is a covoltage function, the associated current
function is the current function which assigns a value of œà(f_1) - œà(f_2) to a directed edge with face f_1 on its left
and f_2 on its right.

sentence:
A medial graph is a piecewise-smooth Jordan curve C ‚äÜ‚Ñù^2, called the boundary curve
and a collection of piecewise-smooth curves ( geodesics ) in the inside of C, each of which is either closed, or has both endpoints on C, satisfying
the following properties:


  * Every intersection of a geodesic with C is transversal.

  * Every intersection between two geodesics or between a geodesic and itself is transversal.

  * There
are no triple intersection points of geodesics or the boundary curve.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A coloring of a medial graph is a function from the cells to the set {black, white} such that directly adjacent cells have opposite colors.
Here we say that two cells are directly adjacent if they share an edge in common.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let M be a colored medial graph.  A conductance structure on M assigns to every interior vertex v an odd bijection Œ≥_v : ‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù.
A conductance structure is monotone if every Œ≥_v is order-preserving, and linear if every Œ≥_v is linear.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
Let M be a colored medial graph and Œ≥ be a conductance structure on M.  A labelling of (M,Œ≥) is a function œï from
the cells of M to ‚Ñù such that for every interior vertex v in M,

    œï(z) - œï(x) = Œ≥_v(œï(w) - œï(y))

where w, x, y, z are the cells in counterclockwise order around v, with w and y colored black.  The boundary
data of a labelling œï is the restriction œï|_‚àÇ of œï to the boundary cells.
The boundary relation Œû_Œ≥ of Œ≥ is the set

    Œû_Œ≥ = {œï|_‚àÇ¬†:¬†œï is a labelling of  (M,Œ≥)}

of all
possible boundary data of labellings of (M,Œ≥).  A colored medial graph M is strongly recoverable if the function Œ≥‚Ü¶Œû_Œ≥
is injective, and M is weakly recoverable if it is injective when restricted to monotone linear Œ≥.

sentence:
A medial graph
is semicritical if the following hold:


  * No geodesic intersects itself

  * If g_1 and g_2 are geodesics, then g_1 and g_2 intersect at most once.

If in addition, every geodesic starts and ends on the boundary curve (rather than being a closed loop), we say that the medial graph is critical .
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A boundary digon or boundary triangle is a simply-connected boundary cell with two or three sides, respectively.  If g is a geodesic which
does not intersect the boundary curve or any other geodesics and which is a simple closed curve, then we call the set of cells inside g a circle .
If there is just one cell, we call it an empty circle .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
If M is a critical medial graph and g is a geodesic, then since M is critical, g divides M into two connected components, by the Jordan curve theorem.
We call such a connected component a side .  If g and h are two geodesics, then g ‚à™ h divides M into four pieces, which we call wedges .
The boundary of any wedge consists of a segment of the boundary curve, which we call the base , and two segments of g and h, which we call the legs .
We call the intersection of g and h the apex of a wedge.  We say that a wedge W is a semiboundary wedge if at least one of the two legs contains no
interior vertices other than the apex.  A boundary zone is one of the following:


  * A semiboundary wedge

  * The side of a geodesic which intersects no other geodesics.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A medial graph is circleless if it has no empty circles.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
If g is a geodesic, we can think of g as either a continuous function on [0,1] or a continuous function on ‚Ñù with period 1.
If [a,b] is a subinterval of the domain of g, and g is injective on both half-open intervals (a,b] and [a,b), we call the curve g([a,b])
a geodesic segment with endpoints g(a) and g(b) .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: geodesic segment with endpoints g(a) and g(b)

sentence:
Let v be an interior vertex.  A 1-lens with pole at v is the interior of a Jordan curve that is a geodesic segment with endpoints v and  v.
Let v and w be interior vertices.  A 2-lens with poles at v and w is the interior of a Jordan curve that is a union of two geodesic segments,
each having endpoints at v and w.  For n = 1, 2, we say that an n-lens is sharp if for every pole v, only one of the four cells that meet at v is
inside the n-lens.  We say that an n-lens is empty if it contains only one cell.

sentence:
If M is a fixed medial graph, a cellset is a set of cells in M.  If M is the medial graph associated
to a bijective network Œì, and S is a cellset, then a labelling of S is a function œï:S ‚Üí‚Ñù
which satisfies (<ref>) whenever w,x,y,z ‚àà S.

sentence:
If S is a cellset and x is a cell not in S, then we say that S ‚à™{x} is a simple extension
of S if there is an interior vertex v of M for which three of the cells around v are in S and x is the fourth.
If there does not exist another interior vertex v' with the same property, then we say that S ‚à™{x} is
a safe simple extension .

sentence:
A cellset S is closed if it has the property that for every interior vertex v of M,
if three of the four cells around v are in S, then so is the fourth.  The smallest closed set
containing S is the closure of S , denoted S.

sentence: A cellset S is safe if (S) = (S).

sentence:
A cellset S is convex if it is an intersection of zero or more pseudo halfplanes.
The convex closure of a cellset S is the smallest convex set containing
S, i.e., the intersection of all half-planes containing S.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If a and b are two cells in a medial graph, we say that a and b are adjacent if they share an edge.  A path
between a and b is a sequence of cells a = x_0, x_1, ‚Ä¶, x_n = b for n ‚â• 0, with x_i adjacent to x_i+1 for each i.
The number n is the length of the path.  A minimal path between two cells is a path of minimal length.  The distance between a
and b , denoted (a,b), is defined to be the length of a minimal path between a and b.
A cellset S is connected
if for every a and b in S, there is a path between a and b containing only cells in S. The connected components of S
are the maximal connected subsets of S.

sentence:
Let (x_1,x_2,‚Ä¶,x_n) and (y_1,y_2,‚Ä¶,y_n) be two paths from a to b.  We say that (y_1,‚Ä¶,y_n) is a simple deformation
of (x_1,‚Ä¶,x_n) if there is some 1 < i < n such that x_j = y_j for j  i, and x_i-1, x_i+1, x_i and y_i are the four cells
surrounding some internal vertex.  We say that (y_1,y_2,‚Ä¶,y_n) is a deformation of (x_1,‚Ä¶,x_n) if it is obtained
by a series of zero or more simple deformations.

[Parking Functions]
A classical parking function of length n is a sequence s ‚àà [n]^n such that for all i ‚àà [n],

    |{j : s_j ‚â• i}| ‚â§ n-i+1.

Additionally, we may consider the case when m ‚â§ n drivers attempt to park. We call these (n,m)-parking functions and the definition is the same as in the classical case for s ‚àà [n]^m.

  (i)‚Ñì=2, (G)=(6), |Œî|=6, |Œ©|=36 and G contains an outer-automorphism of (6),

  (ii)‚Ñì=2, G=(M_12), |Œî|=12 and |Œ©|=144,

sentence:
Assume the Knight-Darwin Law: that G has no infinite path of vertices 
each with <2 parents .
Assume also that A1‚ÄìA4 hold.  Then the following facts are implied:


  * (The Dual Knight-Darwin Law)
No inspecies has an infinite path of vertices each with <2 
children .

  * There are infinitely many individuals each of whom has multiple children.

  * Within an inspecies, every individual has a pair of descendants that breed 
together.

sentence:
Let H be an r-uniform hypergraph of size n. A constructive process ùí´ for H is a finite sequence of hypergraphs H_i, 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ n satisfying the following properties: 




  * H_n = H,

  * H_j is a subhypergraph of H_k for j ‚â§ k, 

  * each H_i has exactly i hyperedges, and 

  * for each j, E(H_j+1) = E(H_j) ‚ãÉ{ e_j } for some e_j ‚àà E(H).


We say that a constructive process ùí´ for a hypergraph H is connected if and only if each H_i is connected for all i.  It is clear that a hypergraph is connected if and only if it has a connected construction process.  We say that a constructive process ùí´ for a hypergraph H is minimally connected if and only if each H_i is minimally connected.

sentence:

sentence:
[ Reduced split tree characterization of general cactus graphs]
  
  A graph G with the reduced split decomposition tree (T,‚Ñ±) is a cactus graph if and only if
  
  
  * ‚Ñ± consists of stars and polygons of size 3 or at least 5;
  
  * the center of every star-node in T is attached to either
    
    
  * a leaf, or
    
  * the center of another star-node, only as long as both star-nodes have exactly two extremities;
    
  
  * every extremity of star-nodes in T is attached to either
    
    
  * a polygon,
    
  * a leaf, or
    
  * an extremity of another star-node;
    
  
  * no two polygons are adjacent.

sentence:
The rightmost BFS tree is the spanning tree T obtained by the following procedure:


Initialization: Set every vertex to be alive . Set the tree T as the tree containing the root-vertex of M and no edge.
 
Core: Consider the alive vertex v which has been in the tree T for the longest time and set it dead.
Inspect the half-edges incident to v in counterclockwise order (starting from the root if v is the root-vertex, and starting from the half-edge following the edge of T leading v to its parent otherwise) and whenever a half-edge leads to a vertex not in the tree T add this vertex and the edge to T.

Repeat until all vertices are dead.

End: Return the spanning tree T.

sentence:
A graph G(V,E) is called a t-expander if and only if the
following holds for any S ‚äÜ V with |S| = t,

    |{v‚àà V-S|uv ‚àâ E  u ‚àà S}|<t.

It is easy to see that the above definition can be restated as
follows: G is a t-expander if and only if G does not
contain a K_t,t as a subgraph. For example, a co-planar graph is a
3-expander.

i) 
If g‚â§ 2 and h‚â§ 2, then 

    4‚àö(2g) + 1 ‚â§ m(g) ‚â§ 4‚àö(g) + 17

    4 ‚àö(h) +1 ‚â§mÃÉ(h) ‚â§ 2‚àö(2h) +17.

ii) If g‚â• 3 and h‚â• 3, then

      and  
    4‚àö(h) + 1 ‚â§mÃÉ(h) ‚â§cÃÉ_h‚àö(h) + 5,

(c_g)_g=3^‚àû and (cÃÉ_h)_h=3^‚àû are decreasing, lim_g‚Üí‚àûc_g = 2‚àö(7)+2<7.3, and lim_h‚Üí‚àûcÃÉ_h = ‚àö(2)(‚àö(7)+1)<5.2.

  Œº‚àà F^-1(ŒΩ) by F are called the children of ŒΩ and we
  denote their set [F]ŒΩ or even ŒΩ if F is clear from

  ŒΩ. Finally, When depicting a tree, we always draw the children
  in increasing order from left to right .

sentence:
Let ‚Ñì_1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì_s be positive integers. An s-legged spider S with length vector (‚Ñì_1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì_s) consists of a vertex u, called the centre of the spider, and paths P_1,‚Ä¶,P_s, called the legs of S, of lengths ‚Ñì_1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì_s, starting at u and sharing no vertex other than u. For convenience, we define two spiders S and S' to be different if P_i‚â† P'_i for some 1‚â§ i‚â§ s, where P'_1,‚Ä¶,P'_s are the legs of S'. So different spiders can form the same graph, e.g. if ‚Ñì_1=‚Ñì_2, P_1=P'_2, P_2=P'_1 and P_i=P'_i for i‚â• 3.
	
	Let v_i be the endpoint of P_i different from u. Then we say that S has leaf vector (v_1,‚Ä¶,v_s).	
	
	
	We say that S' is a subspider of S if they have the same centre and for each 1‚â§ i‚â§ s, the ith leg of S' is a subpath of the ith leg of S.

sentence:
Let L‚â• 1 be a real number. Let f(1,L)=L, and for 2‚â§‚Ñì‚â§ sk, let 
    f(‚Ñì,L)=1+f(‚Ñì-1,L)^16(‚Ñì-1)^2max_1‚â§ i‚â§‚Ñì-1f(i,L)f(‚Ñì-i,L).

	
	We define the notions of L-admissible and L-good paths and spiders recursively as follows.
	
	Every path of length 1 is both L-admissible and L-good. For 2‚â§‚Ñì‚â§ k, we say that a path of length ‚Ñì is L-admissible if each of its proper subpaths is L-good. A path of length¬†‚Ñì is L-good if it is L-admissible and the number of L-admissible paths of length ‚Ñì between their endpoints is at most f(‚Ñì,L).
	
	Every s-legged spider with length vector (1,‚Ä¶,1) is L-admissible. Now let 1‚â§‚Ñì_1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì_s‚â§ k and assume that ‚Ñì_i>1 for some i. A spider with centre u and legs P_i=uw_i,1‚Ä¶ w_i,‚Ñì_i (for 1‚â§ i‚â§ s) is L-admissible if the following two conditions hold:
	
		
  * for any 1‚â§ i‚â§ s and any 1‚â§ j<‚Ñì_i, the s-legged spider with centre u and legs¬†P_1,‚Ä¶,P_i-1,P'_i,P_i+1,‚Ä¶,P_s is L-good, where P'_i=uw_i,1‚Ä¶ w_i,j
		
		
  * for any 1‚â§ i‚â§ s, the path P_i is L-good.
	
	Finally, we say that a spider with length vector (‚Ñì_1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì_s) and leaf vector (v_1,‚Ä¶,v_s) is L-good if it is L-admissible and the number of L-admissible spiders with length vector (‚Ñì_1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì_s) and leaf vector (v_1,‚Ä¶,v_s) is at most f(‚Ñì,L), where ‚Ñì=‚Ñì_1+‚Ä¶+‚Ñì_s.

sentence:
Let H=(V,) be a hypergraph and let c be a coloring c  V ‚Üí.





We say that c is a conflict-free coloring (CF-coloring in short) if every hyperedge S ‚àà contains a uniquely colored vertex, i.e., if there exists a color i ‚àà such that S ‚à© c^-1(i)=1.

For k ‚àà‚Ñï, we say that c is a k-CF-coloring if every hyperedge S ‚àà contains a color that appears at most k times, i.e., if there exists a color i ‚àà such that 1 ‚â§S ‚à© c^-1(i)‚â§ k.

The minimum integer ‚Ñì such that H admits a CF-coloring (respectively, k-CF-coloring) with ‚Ñì colors is called the CF-chromatic (respectively, k-CF-chromatic) number of H and is denoted by œá_cf(H) (respectively, œá_(H)).

sentence:
[Quadratic functions]
Suppose that W is a linear space. By choosing a basis for W we may identify it with F^n for some n. By a quadratic  function on W we mean a function œï : W ‚Üí F of the form œï(x) = x^T M x + r^T x + c, where M is an n √ó n symmetric matrix over F, r ‚àà F^n, and c ‚àà F.  By the rank of œï we understand the rank of the matrix M.
More generally, if W = ·∫Ü + w is an affine space then œï : W ‚Üí F is a quadratic function if the function œïÃá : ·∫Ü‚Üí F defined by œïÃá(x) := œï(x + w) is a quadratic function on ·∫Ü.  We define the rank of œï to be the rank of œïÃá.

sentence:
[Quadratic factors and rank]
Let W be an affine space. Then by a quadratic factor of rank at least r and complexity d we mean a factor = _œï_1,‚Ä¶,œï_d defined by quadratic functions œï_1,‚Ä¶,œï_d : W ‚Üí F which satisfy the rank separation condition (Œª_1 œï_1 + ‚Ä¶ + Œª_d œï_d) ‚â• r whenever Œª_1,‚Ä¶,Œª_d are elements of F, not all zero.

sentence:
[Local factors]  Let W be an affine space.  By a local factor of codimension at most D we mean a factor _1 of W whose atoms are all affine subspaces of W of codimension at most D; note that we allow these subspaces to have different orientations (and even different codimensions).  By a local quadratic factor of codimension at most D, rank at least r, and complexity at most d we mean a pair (_1,_2) of factors, where _1 is a local factor on W of codimension at least D, and _2 is an extension of _1 with the property that on each atom W' of _1, the restriction _2‚áÇ_W' of _2 to W' is a quadratic factor on W of rank at most r and complexity at most d.  

We say that a local quadratic factor ('_1,'_2) is a refinement of another local quadratic factor (_1,_2) if '_1 is a refinement of _1 and '_2 is a refinement of _2.

sentence:
A fold word is a viable representation of a BFB process if and only if it can be reversed with the following algorithm. This identifies the unique reduced BFB sequence responsible for the word.

STEP 1: Take palindromic fold word W=XnX^-1 and undo fold n to construct X. Output n.

STEP 2: Identify the rightmost uniquely occurring symbol m such that the fold word is ZYmY^-1 for some (possibly empty) subsequences Z and Y which do not contain m. Undo m and contract to word W=ZY. Output m.

STEP 3: If W is empty the reduced evolution is the reverse of the output, else repeat STEP 2 .

For a viable BFB fold word W, the evolutionary order of BFBs is precisely the order that their corresponding fold number first appears in the word.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Any m-fold word representing a BFB process has an equivalent representation with a sequence of m integers {r_n} that satisfies -s_n < r_n+1‚â§ s_n where s_n=‚àë_i=1^nr_i>0. Values s_n indicate the number of segments into the structure that we first encounter a copy of folds arising from the n^th BFB cycle. Each term r_n in the sequence represents a BFB event. Negative terms indicate deletion of previous BFBs which shorten the structure. The reduced representation contains strictly positive values and is obtained by combining r_n-1 and r_n into the single term r_n-1+r_n whenever r_n ‚â§ 0. This is repeated until only positive terms remain. The number of reductions using r_n equals the number of BFB events deleted by the n^th event. The direction of all copies of folds from the n^th BFB is given by d_n=p(-1)^s_n, where p is the parity of the initial BFB.

sentence:
Let (D,C) be a Vogan superdiagram.
If i ‚àà C is an even vertex,
we define F_i(D,C) as a new superdiagram (D,C'), where
all the vertices j adjacent to i have reversed their
circling (i.e. they become circled if they were not
and become not circled if they were circled), except
when j is a longer root joint to i by a double edge or j is odd.



In other words, if we define the neighborhood of
vertex i by:

N(i) = {vertices adjacent to  i   excluding   i},
Then F_i(D,C)=(D,C'), where we reverse the circling of all
j ‚àà N(i), except when j is a longer root joint to i
by a double edge or j is odd. 

We also say that the Vogan superdiagram (D,C') is obtained from
(D,C) through the operation F_i. 
The reader can see that an operation F_i can be visually
understood as ‚Äúpressing‚Äù on the vertex i: the vertex itself
will not change the circling, while the adjacent vertices, if
linked by a single edge, will. 

We say that two Vogan superdiagrams are F-related , if
there is a sequence of operations F_i's transforming one
into the other. For example, consider the two diagrams:

sentence: A potential cut (cycle) in a fourientation is the same as a directed cut (cycle) in an ordinary total orientation except that some of the edges may be unoriented (bioriented). More formally, a potential cut (cycle) of a fourientation is a directed cut (cycle) of the oriented graph such that each edge in that cut (cycle) is either oriented in agreement with the cut (cycle) or is unoriented (bioriented). In symbols,¬† is a potential cut belonging to some larger fourientation¬†√ò if e^¬±‚ààùîº() ‚áí e^‚àì‚àâ√ò for all¬†e ‚àà E, and¬† is a potential cycle of¬†√ò if e^¬±‚ààùîº() ‚áí e^¬±‚àà√ò for all¬†e ‚àà E.

sentence: For k, l, m ‚àà‚Ñ§_‚â• 0, a (k,l,m)-fourientation is obtained from a fourientation by assigning each of the oriented edges one of k colors, each of the unoriented edges one of l colors, and each of the bioriented edges one of m colors.  If a variable is set equal to zero, we naturally require that the associated fourientations have no edges with the corresponding fourientation type. We say a¬†(k,l,m)-fourientation is good with respect to a fourientation property if the underlying fourientation is good.

A potential cut  (cycle ) of a fourientation¬†√ò of an ordered, oriented graph  is bad with respect to the min-edge cut (cycle) property defined by¬†(X,Œ¥) if it satisfies both of the following conditions:

  * if e_min is unoriented (bioriented) in √ò then e_min^Œ¥‚ààùîº().

sentence: Let¬†G be a graph and designate a special sink vertex¬†q ‚àà V(G). Set¬†V^q(G) := V(G) ‚àñ{q}. A (G,q)-parking function is an element¬†c = ‚àë_v ‚àà V^q(G)c_v (v) of¬†‚Ñ§V^q(G) so that for every non-empty¬†U ‚äÜ V^q(G), there is¬†u ‚àà U with¬†0‚â§ c_u < d^G_U(u), where¬†d^G_U(u) := |{ e={u,v}‚àà E(U, V(G)‚àñ U)}|. sentence:
A set F={Œ±_1,‚Ä¶,Œ±_t} of new arrows for Q is called an alien set for Q if the following conditions  hold.



  (a) For each Œ±‚àà F there exists a sink vertex z in Q such that s(Œ±),t(Œ±)‚ààSupp I(z).


  (b) t(Œ±)  is not a source vertex in Q unless it is an extremal vertex in Q.

  (d) The quiver Q^F is acyclic.

The arrows in an alien set for Q will be called alien arrows .

sentence:
Reeder's puzzle or Reeder's game consists of a finite connected diagram D with n vertices, the set of all labeling L(D) ‚âÉ (‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§)^n with the set of moves defined in Definition <ref> and its generalization Definition <ref>. The goal of the game is to find the equivalence classes under the above defined relation. A solution of the game for a certain diagram D consists of:


  * Description of the set of the equivalence classes (D)

  * The number of equivalence classes D.

  * For each equivalence class we give a representative with a minimal number of 1's, we call such representative a minimal representative.

  * In certain cases we give a complete description of the equivalence classes.

    1/L_k,      if p ‚â† q, and an edge of length L_k connects p and q.

sentence: A comb graph is a tree with maximum degree three and all degree-three vertices are on a single path.  A pair of initial vertices of a comb graph are two vertices u,v such that every degree-three vertex is an internal vertex on the unique path between u and v.

sentence: A pick comb graph is a graph obtained from either combining a zig-zag path and a comb by identifying the ending vertices of the zig-zag path to a pair of initial vertices of the comb, and/or by connecting the ends of a path to a pair of initial vertices of the comb.

For a sequence ( a_i ) we will write a_i for its
				associated sequence of partial sums a_i = ‚àë_j = 0^i-1
				a_j, with a_0 = 0. For any k-anxious number
				Œ± put

    					{ (a_i)_i = 0^‚àû a_i ‚àà{ 1,‚Ä¶,n }}    if Œ± is not a root of unity,
    { (a_i)_i = 0^Œº-1 a_i ‚àà{ 1,‚Ä¶,n },
    						Œ±^k^a_Œº = Œ±}    if Œ± is a root of unity.

				The k-calmness of a finite sequence of rational functions (

				with respect to a k-anxious number Œ± and a sequence

    _Œ±, (a_i)( c_i ) = ‚àë_i
    					v_Œ±^k^a_i( c_a_i( z ) ).

				The sum is taken over the set { 0, ‚Ä¶, Œº - 1 } for
				Œ± a root of unity and over all natural numbers if it is not a root of
				unity. For simplicity we will usually omit Œ± from the notation.

				It is worth noting that this sum is always either finite or contains an

sentence:
Let 1 ‚â§ l < d, and let G be a graph.  We define
  the l-dimensional affine cover number of¬†G in¬†^d,
  denoted by œÅ^l_d(G), as the minimum number of l-dimensional planes
  in¬†‚Ñù^d such that¬†G has a drawing that is contained in
  the union of these planes.  We define œÄ^l_d(G), the
  weak l-dimensional affine cover number of¬†G in¬†^d,
   similarly to œÅ^l_d(G),
  but under the weaker restriction that the vertices (and not
  necessarily the edges) of¬†G are contained in the union of the
  planes.  Finally, the parallel affine cover number, œÄÃÖ^l_d(G),
  is a restricted version
  of¬†œÄ^l_d(G), in which we insist that the planes are parallel.  We
  consider only straight-line and crossing-free drawings. Note: œÅ^l_d(G),
  œÄ^l_d(G), and œÄÃÖ^l_d(G) are only undefined when d=2 and G is
  non-planar.

sentence:
A proper induced subgraph H of a graph G is an anchor , if it occurs exactly once in graph G. In other words, G  H =1. The induced subgraph on V(G)-V(H) is the residue of H. We denote it by G \ V(H).

 The anchor number of a graph G is the minimum order of the  anchors of G. We denote it by Anch(G).

sentence:
Let H be a subgraph of a graph G and v ‚àà V(G)-V(H). The neighbors of vertex v in subgraph H, i.e. N_v‚à© H, is the shadow of vertex v on the subgraph H .
We denote it by s_v,H (or s_v for simplicity, if H is a specified subgraph).

sentence: Let S={ s_1, s_2,‚ãØ, s_k } be a finite multiset of shadows on a graph G and suppose that A and B are two arbitrary subsets of S.   Two shadow sets A and B are isomorphic , if there is an automorphism of G that maps the subset A to the subset B.

sentence: Let S be a set of shadows on a graph G. A subset A of S is a shadow anchor , if there is not any subset of S which is isomorphic to A.

sentence:
Let H be  a subgraph of a graph G. We define the connection of subgraph H to the rest of graph by triple (H, G\ V(H), S_H ) where S_H is the shadows set that V(H) establish on  G \ V(H)

For two subgraphs H and H' in a graph G. We call the connection H to the rest of graph is similar to the connection of  H' to the rest of graph, if


  I)  Subgraph H is isomorphic to subgraph H'.

  II) Subgraph G \ V(H) is isomorphic to subgraph G \ V(H').

  III)Shadow set S_H is isomorphic to shadow set S_H'.

sentence: We call  H is a connectional anchor of a graph G, if the connection of H to the rest of graph is unique, i.e. there is not any subgraph  with isomorphic  connection. In addition, this distinction should be inferable from the deck.

sentence: An automorphism of a molecular graph Œ≥ is a permutation of the vertices preserving adjacency, taking atoms of a given type to atoms of the same type (e.g., carbons go to carbons, oxygens go to oxygens, and so on).  Aut(Œ≥) is defined as the group of automorphisms of Œ≥.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We define the molecular symmetry group of a molecular graph Œ≥ as the subgroup of Aut(Œ≥) induced by chemically possible motions taking the molecule to itself together with reflections which take the molecule to itself.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

The pegging number P(G) of a graph G is the smallest natural number such that G is peggable by every distribution of size P(G). 
	The optimal-pegging number p(G) of G is the minimum size of all distributions on G that can peg G.

sentence:
[Hierarchically clustered trees]
Consider SFP on  with d ‚â• 1, i.i.d. vertex weights whose law W satisfies (<ref>), with 1<Œ≥<2, and any Œª >0. 	
Let ùíÆ_m denote the SFP configuration inside the cube [0,m-1]^d. 
There exist Œæ >0, a density 0 < œÅ‚â§ 1, K>0 and a constant m_0>0, such that 


  * for all m‚â• m_0,

    (ùíÆ_m contains a (0, m, œÅ,K)-hierarchically clustered tree)‚â• 1-exp(-œÅ m^Œæ),  and


  * the infinite component ùíû_‚àû contains a.s. an infinite, connected, cycle-free subgraph ùíØ_‚àû such that if we remove any given edge from ùíØ_‚àû, a finite and infinite connected component remain and there exist x‚àà and m‚â• 1 such that the finite connected component is an (x, m, œÅ,K)-hierarchically clustered tree.

sentence:
[Scale-free percolation]
					Consider the graph (, √ó) for some fixed d‚â•1. Assign to each vertex x‚àà an i.i.d. weight W_x, where the weights follow a power-law distribution with parameter œÑ-1:
					
    (W_x>w)= w^-(œÑ-1)L(w),      w > 0,

					where L is a slowly-varying function (i.e., L(wa)/L(w)‚Üí1 for all a>0 as w‚Üí‚àû, so the law of W_x is (œÑ-1)-regularly varying).
					Conditionally on the weights, an edge {x,y}‚àà√ó is retained independently of all other edges with probability 
					
    p_xy=1-exp(-ŒªW_xW_y/| x-y|^Œ±),

					where | x|= x _1 and Œª, Œ±>0 are positive constants of the model.[We choose to work with the ‚Ñì_1-norm because it is a practical metric, but defining SFP with respect to any ‚Ñì_p-norm with p ‚àà [1,‚àû] gives qualitatively similar results.] The edge is removed otherwise. We call retained edges open , and removed edges closed.
We denote the joint probability measure of edge occupation and weights by _(Œª,W) (where the subscript W refers to the law of the weights, not the actual values) and write just  if the parameters are clear from the context.
